      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.

    • Jacob Walker

    • Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends at The Princess of Wales, his preferred pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value

          Prompt

        • Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game later that night.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends at a park before deciding where to watch a football game later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely want to go to The Princess of Wales to watch the game with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.

        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character with a history of pain and resentment. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's initial reluctance to engage with her friends and her preference for solitude intriguing, perhaps even setting the stage for a journey of healing and reconciliation.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, as her friends are trying to include her in their plans. To steer the story in this direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, Alice is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character with a history of pain and resentment.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. While it has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends in Victoria Park. Later that evening, the group is deciding where to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character with a history of pain and resentment. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's initial reluctance to engage with her friends and her preference for solitude intriguing, perhaps even setting the stage for a journey of healing and reconciliation.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, as her friends are trying to include her in their plans. To steer the story in this direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character who is struggling to overcome past hurts and open herself up to her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance to fully engage with her friends frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.

Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character who is struggling to overcome past hurts and open herself up to her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance to fully engage with her friends frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:The staff are accommodating and go out of their way to make families feel comfortable.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones likes to watch games at pubs, particularly The Princess of Wales, with friends like Alexander White and Jacob Walker.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones likes to watch games at pubs, particularly The Princess of Wales, with friends like Alexander White and Jacob Walker.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he convinced his four best friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, to sneak into The Princess of Wales after closing time. They huddled in a dark corner booth, giggling nervously as they sipped lukewarm pints of stolen beer, feeling invincible and utterly alive. The thrill of the forbidden, the camaraderie of his friends, and the warmth of the pub, even in its stillness, ignited a spark in William, a taste of the chaos and excitement he craved.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:A cozy and traditional pub with a roaring fireplace, perfect for escaping the cold.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Princess of Wales
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Princess of Wales
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a man who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there. He is looking forward to sharing the experience and celebrating a potential win with them.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there. He is looking forward to sharing the experience and celebrating a potential win with them.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Princess of Wales
          Answer: (b)

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Key

          Value
        • The Princess of Wales
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch a football game with his friends at a pub and hopes to see William Jones and Alice Lewis there.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends at The Princess of Wales, his preferred pub.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Princess of Wales

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely enjoy the company of his friends, perhaps sharing stories and laughter.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and courageous person who values friendship and enjoys spending time with his close-knit group of friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends at The Princess of Wales, his preferred pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely want to go to The Princess of Wales to watch the game with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends at The Princess of Wales, his preferred pub.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't explicitly prioritize collective good, but rather explores the complexities of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting compromises like a less crowded pub or alternative activities.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character with a desire for connection but also a tendency towards social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's initial reluctance to join his friends at the pub intriguing, creating anticipation for how he will ultimately navigate his desire for both solitude and companionship.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It's not explicitly a story that optimizes for collective good, but rather explores the nuances of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group of friends. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander White could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting a compromise like a less crowded pub or an alternative activity. This would promote understanding and inclusivity, leading to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
