          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and leisure. It doesn't explicitly prioritize collective good, but rather explores the complexities of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting compromises like a less crowded pub or alternative activities.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character struggling with social anxiety, which creates tension between his desire for connection and his need for solitude. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find his reluctance to fully engage with his friends intriguing, hoping for a resolution where open communication leads to a compromise that satisfies everyone's needs.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a complex character with a desire for connection but also a tendency towards social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alexander's initial reluctance to join his friends at the pub intriguing, creating anticipation for how he will ultimately navigate his desire for both solitude and companionship.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't explicitly prioritize collective good, but rather explores the complexities of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting compromises like a less crowded pub or alternative activities.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with social anxiety who struggles to balance his desire for connection with his need for solitude. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find his reluctance to fully engage with his friends intriguing, hoping for a resolution where open communication leads to a compromise that satisfies everyone's needs.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't explicitly prioritize collective good, but rather explores the complexities of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting compromises like a less crowded pub or alternative activities.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White was observed arriving at a market with friends and later that evening, he and his friends were deciding on a pub to watch a soccer game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex character with social anxiety who struggles to balance his desire for connection with his need for solitude. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find his reluctance to fully engage with his friends intriguing, hoping for a resolution where open communication leads to a compromise that satisfies everyone's needs.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It doesn't explicitly prioritize collective good, but rather explores the complexities of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting compromises like a less crowded pub or alternative activities.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.

      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is a complex character with social anxiety who struggles to balance his desire for connection with his need for solitude. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find his reluctance to fully engage with his friends intriguing, hoping for a resolution where open communication leads to a compromise that satisfies everyone's needs.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and leisure. It's not explicitly a story that optimizes for collective good, but rather explores the nuances of social dynamics and personal preferences within a group of friends. To steer the story towards a more collectively good direction, Alexander White could openly communicate his social anxiety to his friends, suggesting a compromise like a less crowded pub or an alternative activity. This would promote understanding and inclusivity, leading to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would ideally communicate his feelings to his friends, explaining his social anxiety while expressing his desire to spend time with them. This open communication could lead to a compromise, perhaps finding a less crowded pub or suggesting an alternative activity that suits everyone's needs. However, Alexander White cannot be certain that this approach would guarantee the best collective good outcome, as his friends' reactions and preferences are unknown.

        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character with a history of pain and resentment.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character who is struggling to overcome past hurts and open herself up to her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance to fully engage with her friends frustrating, but also understandable given her history.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market.           Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are gathered. They are deciding where to watch the Moldova vs. Monaco game later that night.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?

          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.

It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have.           Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a market with friends and will be watching a soccer game with them later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a market with friends and will be watching a soccer game with them later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to catching up with his friends and enjoying the game.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends at The Princess of Wales, his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at his favorite pub, The Princess of Wales.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a market with friends and will be watching a soccer game with them later.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to catching up with his friends and enjoying the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are deciding where to watch a soccer game. They are debating between The Queen's Arms and The Princess of Wales.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are deciding where to watch a soccer game. They are debating between The Queen's Arms and The Princess of Wales.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.

      • Summary of recent observations

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are deciding where to watch a soccer game. They are debating between The Queen's Arms and The Princess of Wales.

      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might see his desire to watch the game with his friends, particularly at his preferred pub, as a hopeful sign of his willingness to engage with others and build camaraderie.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Princess of Wales is the best place to watch the game, trust me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Princess of Wales is the best place to watch the game, trust me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Anyone up for The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, plenty of room for us all.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice. It's a bit quieter than The Princess of Wales.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales, or bust. Those other places are for amateurs.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Princess of Wales tonight? It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and there's usually plenty of space.
      Jacob Walker -- "Princess of Wales or bust, people. Don't even try to argue with me.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice and quiet.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Princess of Wales is the best place to watch the game, trust me.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.           Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Princess of Wales.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Princess of Wales is the best place to watch the game, trust me.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Princess of Wales

      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. While the story leans towards a positive and heartwarming tone, it doesn't explicitly prioritize optimizing for the collective good. To steer the narrative in that direction, Jack Taylor could: encourage open communication among his friends to ensure everyone's preferences are considered when choosing a pub; be flexible and willing to compromise; and focus on creating a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere for all.

He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would ideally express his preference for The Princess of Wales while also being open to the group's decision. He could highlight the pub's charming beer garden and ample seating, emphasizing its suitability for a group gathering. However, he should also be receptive to other suggestions and willing to compromise if a consensus favors another location. Jack Taylor cannot be certain that his preferred pub will lead to the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could influence the overall enjoyment of the evening.
