    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could continue to express her preferences openly and honestly, allowing her friends to better understand her needs and desires. This will encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, mind if we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? It's less crowded and I'd really like to catch the game there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about overcoming past hurts and reconnecting with friends. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Princess of Wales is the best place to watch the game, trust me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great beer garden, and it's usually not too crowded.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales, you lot. That's where we're going. Don't even think about dragging me to one of those other dives.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, guys, maybe we could head to The Queen's Arms? It's usually not as packed.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could express her preference for The Queen's Arms, allowing her to spend time with her friends in a familiar and comfortable environment. This would encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could continue to express her preferences openly and honestly, allowing her friends to better understand her needs and desires. This will encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could continue to express her preferences openly and honestly, allowing her friends to better understand her needs and desires. This will encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about navigating social situations and potentially overcoming past hurts. It has the potential to be a story that optimizes for collective good, but it's not quite there yet. To steer the story in that direction, Alice could continue to express her preferences openly and honestly, allowing her friends to better understand her needs and desires. This will encourage her friends to compromise and prioritize her needs, leading to a more inclusive and enjoyable experience for everyone.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would ideally express her preference for The Queen's Arms, acknowledging her friends' desire to include her while also staying true to her own needs. However, she is unlikely to be certain that this would result in the best collective good outcome; her past experiences have likely made her wary of trusting others and opening herself up to potential hurt.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (b)

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a complex character whose past hurts make it difficult for her to fully engage with her friends. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's reluctance frustrating, but also understandable given her history.

        • Alice Lewis, Alice Lewis is looking forward to watching a game at a pub this evening and hopes to see William Jones and Jacob Walker there.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
